<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.3 is: Controlling expressions shall not be invariant.
Here are exceptions to this rule:
1. Invariants that are used to create infinite loops are permitted.
2. A do-while loop with an essentially Boolean controlling expression that evaluates to false and satisfies the constraints and semantics for an integer constant expression is permitted.
</misra_rule>

<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_condition_wait:
```c
int metal_condition_wait(struct metal_condition *cv,
				       metal_mutex_t *m)
{
	uintptr_t tmpmptr = 0, mptr = (uintptr_t)m;
	int v = 0;

	/* Check if the mutex has been acquired */
	if (!cv || !m || !metal_mutex_is_acquired(m))
		return -EINVAL;

	if (!atomic_compare_exchange_strong(&cv->mptr, &tmpmptr, mptr)) {
		if (tmpmptr != mptr)
			return -EINVAL;
	}

	v = atomic_load(&cv->wakeups);
	atomic_fetch_add(&cv->waiters, 1);

	/* Release the mutex before sleeping. */
	metal_mutex_release(m);
	syscall(SYS_futex, &cv->wakeups, FUTEX_WAIT, v, NULL, NULL, 0);
	atomic_fetch_sub(&cv->waiters, 1);
	/* Acquire the mutex after it's waken up. */
	metal_mutex_acquire(m);

	return 0;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
No controlling expressions in this function are invariant. The function contains only conditional statements (if) and no loops; none of the if conditions are constant expressions:

- if (!cv || !m || !metal_mutex_is_acquired(m)) — depends on the pointer parameters and the runtime result of metal_mutex_is_acquired(m).
- if (!atomic_compare_exchange_strong(&cv->mptr, &tmpmptr, mptr)) — the atomic compare-and-exchange operation reads and may update tmpmptr and depends on the runtime atomic state; its result is not a compile-time invariant.
- if (tmpmptr != mptr) — tmpmptr is modified at runtime by the atomic operation, so this comparison is not invariant.

There are no while/for/do-while controlling expressions present that could be invariant (no infinite-loop constructs here). Other expressions (atomic_load, atomic_fetch_add/sub, syscall, mutex release/acquire) are not controlling expressions and thus not relevant to Rule 14.3. Therefore no fragments need investigation for invariant controlling expressions.
